text: Take me by the hand—let's run! (The king1:4. In love poetry of the time “king” was also a term of endearment. has brought me to his bedroom.) Let's be happy together and find pleasure in your love.1:4. The verb moves to the first person plural, which could mean the change of speaker (some versions believe this line is spoke by the “friends” of the woman). However, it is taken here to be an inclusive form, indicating the woman and the man together. Your love is far better than wine! Women are right to adore you so!1:4. Referring back to the young women of verse 3.
